title: Extravagant edibles event a treat
text:
2015 Geelong Food and Wine Extravaganza a sweet treat for foodies by: What are these? James, 6, and Emma, 7, taste locally-made treats by Freckleberry at the Extravaganza event. Pictures: Glenn Ferguson Source: News Limited 
GEELONG foodies had the chance to eat, drink, and discover at the third annual Food and Wine Extravaganza at Deakin University on Saturday. 
A massive 55 stalls and 12 chefs set up at the Waterfront campus for the event, which featured everything from scone-baking competitions, to spice masterclasses, to exhibitions on sustainable produce. 
Those with a sweet tooth were sure to swing by the stall of local chocolatier Megan Van Oirschot, the owner of South Geelong chocolate factory Freckleberry. 
Ms Van Oirschot used the Extravaganza to launch Freckleberry’s new range of delicious fudge treats. 
The fudge flavours included mint, peanut butter, vanilla, banana, jaffa and raspberry — and chocolate of course. 
“We’re going to be coming up with some new creations now we’ve got our machinery all set up,” Ms Van Oirschot said. Bistro at Banks’ Tao Tobayiwa shows off a basket of fresh sourdough. Source: News Limited 
“We do lots of chocolate-making instore, and people can always come along and watch.” 
Though it was her first Extravaganza, Ms Van Oirschot said she was very pleased with the event. 
“It’s a good show — it’s nice to do a show with a bit more of a community feel to it,” she said. 
Renowned British chef and Victorian Farmers’ Market Association ambassador Matt Wilkinson, who runs Brunswick’s Pope Joan restaurant and cafe, also dropped by to show off his skills and speak to industry professionals. 
Other exhibitors shared a taste of their cheese, cider, olive oil, fresh bread and plenty more. 
Extravaganza president Penny Whitehead said attendees had a “plethora of options” to choose from, including some fine wines from local wineries, which she called “one of the region’s best assets”. 
“There are loads of local producers here,” Ms Whitehead said. 
“You can just have a wine and settle in.” 
The culinary circus wrapped up at 6pm on Saturday night. 
Extravaganza staff estimated more than 3000 attendees filled their bellies at the event.
